sentences.sentence: So the Nightingale( 夜莺 ) flew over to the Rose Tree that was growing outside the Student’s window.
“Give me a red rose,” she said, “and I will sing you my sweetest song.”
But the Tree shook its head.
“My roses are red,” it answered,
“as red as the sun before it sets, and redder than a forest fire.
But last winter’s storms broke many of my branches( 树枝 ), the spring was cold, and the frost( 霜冻 ) killed my flowers.
I will have no roses at all this year.”
“One red rose is all I want,” said the Nightingale( 夜莺 ),
“only one red rose! Is there no way to get it?”
“There is a way,” answered the Tree, “but it is so terrible that I do not want to tell you what it is.”
“Tell me,” said the Nightingale( 夜莺 ). “I am not afraid.”
“If you want a red rose,” said the Tree,
“you must sing to me in the Moonlight, and color the rose with the blood of your own heart.
You must sing to me with your chest( 胸膛 ) pressed against one of my thorns( 刺 ).
All night long you must sing to me.
The thorn( 刺 ) must pierce( 刺破 ) your heart, and your blood must flow( 流淌 ) into my veins( 叶脉 ) and become mine.”
“Death is a great price to pay for a red rose,” said the Nightingale( 夜莺 ).
“Life is very dear to all.
It is pleasant to sit in the green forest, to see the golden light of the rising sun, and the silver light of the rising moon.
How wonderful it is to smell the sweet flowers on the trees and in the fields.
Yet love is better than life, and what is the heart of a bird compared to( 与...相比 ) the heart of a man?”
So she spread her brown wings and flew into the sky.
She passed over the garden like a shadow( 影子 ), and like a shadow( 影子 ) she drifted back( 飘回 )across the forest.
The young Student was still lying on the grass, where she had left him, and the tears( 眼泪 ) were not yet dry in his beautiful eyes.
“Be happy,” said the Nightingale( 夜莺 ). “You will have your red rose.
I will make it out of my music in the moonlight, and color it with the blood of my own heart.
All that I ask of you in return is that you will be a true lover.
Love has more wisdom than all the books which wise men have written.
It is the most powerful force in the world.
A kiss from a lover is sweeter than honey( 蜂蜜 ), and fresher than a flower in springtime.”
The Student looked up from the grass, and listened, but he could not understand what the Nightingale( 夜莺 ) was saying to him,
because he only knew about the things that are written down in books.
But the Oak( 橡树 ) Tree understood, and felt sad, because he liked the little Nightingale( 夜莺 ) very much.
“Sing me one last song,” he said softly.
“I will feel very lonely when you are gone.”
So the Nightingale( 夜莺 ) sang to the Oak( 橡树 ) Tree, and her voice sounded sweeter than anything he had heard before.
When she had finished her song the Student got up, and pulled out a notebook and a pencil from his pocket.
“The bird’s song was beautiful,” he said to himself, as he walked back through the forest.
“But did she truly have feeling? I am afraid not.
In fact, this bird is like most artists, all style and no substance( 实质 ).
Still, there were some truly beautiful notes( 音调 ) in her voice.
What a pity that they do not mean anything, or serve any useful purpose.”
The Student went into his room to lie down on his bed, and he began to think about his love.
After a short time, he fell asleep.
